abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Primary ciliary dyskinesia (PCD), a disorder of the motile cilia, is now recognised as an underdiagnosed cause of bronchiectasis. Accurate PCD diagnosis comprises clinical assessment, analysis of cilia and the identification of biallelic variants in one of 50 known PCD-related genes, including <jats:italic>HYDIN</jats:italic>. <jats:italic>HYDIN</jats:italic>-related PCD is underdiagnosed due to the presence of a pseudogene, <jats:italic>HYDIN2</jats:italic>, with 98% sequence homology to <jats:italic>HYDIN</jats:italic>. This presents a significant challenge for Short-Read Next Generation Sequencing (SR-NGS) and analysis, and many diagnostic PCD gene panels do not include <jats:italic>HYDIN</jats:italic>. We have used a combined approach of SR-NGS with bioinformatic masking of <jats:italic>HYDIN2</jats:italic>, and state-of-the-art long-read Nanopore sequencing (LR_NGS), together with analysis of respiratory cilia including transmission electron microscopy and immunofluorescence to address the underdiagnosis of <jats:italic>HYDIN</jats:italic> as a cause of PCD. Bioinformatic masking of <jats:italic>HYDIN2</jats:italic> after SR-NGS facilitated the detection of biallelic <jats:italic>HYDIN</jats:italic> variants in 15 of 437 families, but compromised the detection of copy number variants. Supplementing testing with LR-NGS detected <jats:italic>HYDIN</jats:italic> deletions in 2 families, where SR-NGS had detected a single heterozygous <jats:italic>HYDIN</jats:italic> variant. LR-NGS was also able to confirm true homozygosity in 2 families when parental testing was not possible. Utilising a combined genomic diagnostic approach, biallelic <jats:italic>HYDIN</jats:italic> variants were detected in 17 families from 242 genetically confirmed PCD cases, comprising 7% of our PCD cohort. This represents the largest reported <jats:italic>HYDIN</jats:italic> cohort to date and highlights previous underdiagnosis of <jats:italic>HYDIN</jats:italic>-associated PCD. Moreover this provides further evidence for the utility of LR-NGS in diagnostic testing, particularly for regions of high genomic complexity.</jats:p>

assertion.name: Ethics
assertion.value: DEM is on a scientific advisory board at ONT, is engaged in a research agreement with ONT, and they have paid for him to travel to speak on their behalf. DEM holds stock options in MyOme.

assertion.name: Ethics
assertion.value: All participating institutions received approval from local institutional review boards. Informed consent was obtained from all subjects, and any clinical data has been de-identified.

publisher: Springer Science and Business Media LLC
